labels.name: duplicate
labels.description: This issue or pull request already exists

labels.name: wontfix
labels.description: This will not be worked on

issues.title: A more high-level introduction
issues.author: yaronf
issues.body:
Since this is the core document of the working group, I think the Intro should start with a much simpler paragraph saying what this is all about. Here's a shot at it:

> Modern financial and commercial networks often transfer digital assets between individuals and companies. Digital assets have many forms, including cryptocurrencies, fiat money equivalents such as CBDC, titles that represent ownership of physical assets and more. Numerous networks exist that allow to transfer such assets between network members, but interoperability between networks barely exists. The goal of the SAT Protocol is to enable digital asset transfer between networks, regardless of the networks' internal structure and technology.

comments.author: yaronf
comments.body: Reopening per my comment to #5 (otherwise please close this issue).

issues.title: What is App2?
issues.author: yaronf
issues.body: In Sec. 3.2, we mention the applications App1 and App2. App2 is mentioned with no explanation. So first, we need to define that App2 is the Beneficiary application. But more importantly, I think it is rare that there's an application on the beneficiary side. In some cases (fiat currency and cryptocurrency) there may just be a passive account.

comments.author: findthomas
comments.body:
This is a problematic area generally, because SATP needs to work for: (a) UTXO-based networks, and (b) Account-based networks, (c) Monolithic/legacy databases fronted by gateways, and (d) some future asset-control mechanism.

Today, I think the best we can say is that " App2 controls the assets of the Beneficiary in NW2" (and same thing for App1 and the Originator in NW1).

comments.author: yaronf
comments.body: And add a comment that in some cases, there may be no App2?

issues.title: Gateway message signatures in the Assumptions section
issues.author: yaronf
issues.body: The fact that all messages are signed/verified is not an assumption, it is a protocol requirement.

comments.author: findthomas
comments.body: Thanks Yaron. Agree. I will correct this and mention this point up-front.

comments.author: yaronf
comments.body: Process comment: I suggest to keep issues open until a PR is merged that addresses them. Otherwise we can easily lose them.

issues.title: Sec. 3.3: Assets will be "technically" owned
issues.author: yaronf
issues.body:
There's nothing technical about ownership. It is a legal term, and I doubt that it applies here. It may be an escrow arrangement, for example.

Similarly in Sec. 8, "G2 is still the owner".

We may want to replace the legal term "to own" by the more technical "to manage" (an asset), and explain what it means.

comments.author: findthomas
comments.body:
>>> Temporary asset mint (3.2): Gateway G2 creates (mints) an
>>> equivalent asset in NW2 assigned to itself as the owner.  This
>>> step can be reversed (i.e. asset destroyed) in the case of the
>>> failure in the commitment steps because G2 is still the owner of
>>> the asset in NW2.

We could improve this description. 

And yes, G2 at this point is the legal owner and technical holder (holder of the key-pair that controls the asset in NW2).

issues.title: Are gateways "trusted"?
issues.author: yaronf
issues.body:
Sec. 3.3 mentions that gateways are trusted to carry out the protocol correctly. This also means they are trusted from a security point of view.

I think this is incorrect. IMO, from a security POV:
* There is mutual trust between each gateway and the network that it represents.
* When running the SAT protocol, GW1 is able to verify that GW2 is following the protocol correctly.
* However, GW1 still relies on the veracity of GW2's signed statements (e.g. that it has extinguished an asset), and vice versa. The truth of such statements may need to be enforced by mechanisms (e.g. legal procedures) that are outside our scope.

issues.title: Data transfer interop mode: is it needed?
issues.author: yaronf
issues.body: "Data transfer" needs to be clarified or maybe removed. What do we mean by "transfer of data only under authorization", what is the state this bullet refers to, why do we even need a 2PC protocol for data transfer?

comments.author: findthomas
comments.body:
Previously we had a long text in the older versions of the draft (before the draft become formal WG item) discussing the 3 modes. The group then agreed with the Chairs that this work should be postponed until we finish the current set of drafts.

If you are interested, Rama has moved some of the text about views and data sharing to the following two Individual drafts:

https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-ramakrishna-satp-views-addresses/

https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-ramakrishna-satp-data-sharing/

comments.author: yaronf
comments.body: So let's say that this is currently out of scope, and include an informational reference to https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-ramakrishna-satp-data-sharing/ for clarity.

issues.title: Desirable properties
issues.author: yaronf
issues.body:
* Durability: I suggest to remove this one, because it seems to be a property of each network rather than the protocol.
* Byzantine correctness (maybe there is a better term for this): the protocol needs to survive not only unintentional failures, but also intentional failures and corruptions caused by one of the gateways being malicious.

comments.author: findthomas
comments.body:
Actually, the ACID properties applies to the 2PC transaction itself (in classical distribute database designs), and not the databases or networks themselves. Some databases implement Transaction Monitors (TM) as endpoints (fronting the database) to permit the database to participate in the distributed transactions.

In the case of SATP, the TM construct is represented by the Gateways.


>>> Byzantine correctness (maybe there is a better term for this): 
>>> the protocol needs to survive not only unintentional failures, 
>>> but also intentional failures and corruptions caused by one of 
>>> the gateways being malicious.

This is a topic that the WG has not yet discussed in-depth. For example, what if G2 purposely tries to deny transfers from completing.

comments.author: yaronf
comments.body: IMO eventually you'd need a legal action, hence my text in #13. So yes, we need to be very crisp when defining this property.

issues.title: Crash recovery and backup gateways
issues.author: yaronf
issues.body:
* 5.4, first paragraph: we just said we only support one gateway per network, and now we say there are several! It's probably a matter of terminology: should we speak about gateway clusters and cluster members? 
* 5.4: I disagree that we need to standardize log data for interoperability. IMO this is not the case, because cluster behavior is almost always an internal implementation detail, people usually don't try to mix multiple vendors in a cluster. IMO we only standardize it because it is error prone, and if we don't define it in detail, people will get it wrong.

comments.author: findthomas
comments.body:
For 5.4 1st paragraph:  The paragraph can be improved. There may be several gateways (e.g. N) in front of a given network. For crash-recovery using the primary-backup strategy, each gateway would always need a backup (shadow).  The implementation question becomes:  does a network actually have 2N gateways (N active; N shadow), or is it the case that the shadows are actually other gateways in the set of N.

Perhaps this is a topic for the group to discuss.

For 5.4 on standardized logs, I think we mean "standardized" within each network, so that each gateway has the ability to parse through the logs of other gateways in the sane network (assuming access is granted). 

Also, the term "logs" here is used to mean log of the SATP messages that have been sent/received by a gateway. (It's not "logs" in the broad sense of the word).

We will fix the text to make these points clear.

issues.title: Stage 0: a black sheep?
issues.author: yaronf
issues.body:
I don't see how we can ever have interoperability if Stage 0 is out of scope. We could define a minimal set of data elements being transmitted, and expect extensions to cover the legal requirements that will for sure pop up. There is no forward compatibility issue because gateways can always refuse incoming requests.

Also, version negotiation should be in Stage 0 and not Stage 1 (see Sec. 9).

comments.author: findthomas
comments.body:
Agree.  We are early days in working on Stage-0 in that we have just started discussing Stage-0 in earnest in the past 3 months.

This was the focus of Denis' presentation at IETF117.

issues.title: Attestation out of scope?
issues.author: yaronf
issues.body:
Sec. 6: Why is attestation even in scope? We are setting up a secure channel, and this may include (per policy on both gateways) authentication of both sides, and possibly attestation. But ideally, this should all be done at the TLS layer.

And then there's the question whether it is even expected. Typically in a cross-domain setting, authentication is much more relevant than attestation.

comments.author: findthomas
comments.body:
Hi Yaron,

Using one example, the Lock-Attestations (set of asset-related claims) is above the TLS layer. 

It has to be a standalone blob & signed by G1, so that it can be stored by both gateways for future legal disputes.

When we use the word "Attestation" or "Receipt" we are using it in a legal sense, similar to signing a Word/PDF doc or JSON which in the US is covered under thew Clinton's eSignature ACT of 2000.

The "Attestation" is more like a legal/financial assurance and the willingness of the  Owner/Operator of a Gateway G1 to take-on financial liabilities if G1 lies or makes a mistake.

ps. I think the word "Attestation" maybe confusing here.  We did look at the word "Claim" (as in signed claims or assertion).

comments.author: yaronf
comments.body: I'm confused: Sec. 6 talks about *device* attestation, and points to the RATS working group. In the context of RATS attestation is the guarantee that a certain piece of software is running on a device that has some properties. It is nothing to do with legal assurances.

comments.author: findthomas
comments.body:
Apologies Yaron,

I was looking at the wrong text :-)

>>> Mutual device attestations: In cases where device attestation
>>> [RATS] is required, each gateway must yield attestation evidence
>>> to the other regarding its configuration.  A gateway may take on
>>>  the role as a attestation verifier, or it may rely on an external
>>>  verifier to appraise the received evidence.

RATS device-attestation is mentioned as a possible future capability that is not currently out-of-scope for the SATP WG.

If RATS WG could pick-up this item (e.g. define SBOM etc for gateways), that would be great.

comments.author: yaronf
comments.body: It's not clear from the document that this is out of scope and pending a potential RATS action.

issues.title: Legal Considerations
issues.author: yaronf
issues.body:
I'm afraid there's no escaping it. Here's some proposed text that may be included as it own section or incorporated into Policy Considerations. And yes, it needs to be approved by a legal expert.

# Legal Considerations
For each pair of gateways, G1 and G2, representing the networks NW1 and NW2, the following legal guarantees must exist in order for this protocol to be effective: These guarantees should be enacted as a combination of legislation in the relevant jurisdictions, and binding contracts.
* G1 is allowed to act on behalf of NW1, and similarly G2 with NW2.
* G1 is liable for statements that it digitally signs, and similarly G2.
* G2 is allowed to mint assets that were originally minted by NW1, and those assets have the same standing as the originals.

comments.author: findthomas
comments.body:
Thanks for the text. Yes agree, there is no escaping.

If no one objects, we could paste it into the next rev of the SATP-Architecture draft
